awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Nested Black-Box Constructions in Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
Secure computation is a broad topic in cryptography that deals with how to compute functions over distributed private data. At the most basic level, the security of this task is derived from simple, low level, cryptographic primitives. A central question in this area is whether the code of the low level primitives is required to securely compute the desired function. This question has remained largely unexplored for the case of cryptographic functions. The project's novelties are new enhancements to classical cryptographic primitives, and a new paradigm to securely compute any function instantiated from them without requiring its full code. The project's impacts are discovery of new and general-purpose tools that have the potential to transform the area of black-box secure computation.

The project takes a fresh look at the case of functions that depend only on input/output behavior of other cryptographic primitives and not their code. Existing methods to securely compute such functions require the code of the primitives they depend on even though the functions themselves do not. Such functions, referred to as nested black-box functions, happen to be a major source of inefficiency in secure computation. It is argued that if classical cryptographic primitives such as one-way functions admit sufficiently powerful secure computation protocols, it may be possible to avoid the need for their code when computing nested black-box functions instantiated from them. This project explores ways to construct these enhanced primitives from classical ones in a black-box manner, and general-purpose methods to securely compute nested black-box functions instantiated from them.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated foundational issues concerning the efficiency of cryptographic protocols involving two or more mutually distrustful parties. The project was particularly concerned with the black-box notion of efficiency where the goal is to design protocols whose efficiency is independent of the code, or the implementation details, of its cryptographic components. This property becomes highly non-trivial when multiple, nested calls maybe made to cryptographic functions within a complex protocol such as a zero-knowledge proof or a secure multiparty computation protocol.

The project proposed and successfully constructed novel extensions of several cryptographic functions. These extensions made it possible to prove statements in zero-knowledge for tasks involving nested calls to these functions without violating the black-box (efficiency) requirement. In particular, objects such as one-way functions and collision-resistant hash functions can be generically extended to support such black-box zero-knowledge proofs. The project also developed lower bounds highlighting necessary changes that must be made to more advanced functions such as pseudorandom generators and functions. Finally, novel approaches were developed to obtain efficient constructions for a number of advanced objects including post-quantum secure compact ring-signatures, concretely efficient non-malleable zero-knowledge under minimal assumptions, two-round protocols for set-membership tasks, and new black-box techniques for non-malleable commitments.  The techniques developed here unify various methods in black-box cryptography, and will prove useful in the design of future cryptographic applications.

Majority of the research work was performed in collaboration with graduate students at various stages of their career, advancing the goal of training the next generation of workforce. The project also supported educational goals at PI's home institution in the form cryptography courses and seminars on these topics. The results were widely disseminated through a variety of publicly accessible outlets including conference papers, research talks, and presentation slides.
